THIS...is why we're here. Grab a tissue, and read to the end.üíû

One cadet's answer to the question-What has been one of your favorite UMA moments or memories this year?

" The bus rides for basketball, the dumb interactions in the hallway. Snow-cones in the Mrs. Daniels room. A shot in the leg from a tootsie roll. So many things that are distinctly UMA and make me feel at home. I've grown a lot this year and experienced more. I fell for someone for the first time and got to feel the pain of rejection. I was pushed just a little bit this year and got to feel the reward of hard work. I got to see a community mourn and rely on each other, a beautiful thing. The days tend to slip by so fast that I forget how lucky I am to live my life and do what I do. It isn't always perfect but I wouldn't have it any other way than UMA."

We are so proud to congratulate Cadets Brendan Lee and Cami Kaiser!! Both were accepted into the first ever Air Force JROTC Cyber Academy this summer. This was an amazingly competitive process in selecting the first class. They are 2 of only 20 cadets nationwide to be selected for this fantastic new program. Shows what a great job Mr Storm, our JROTC instructors, in fact all of our teachers do to prepare our cadets to do amazing things.

They will get an all expense paid trip to Mississippi State University for four weeks to learn about cyber security and earn college credit. At the end of their training they get to spend a week at Maxwell AFB, Alabama where they will work side by side with cyber experts of our own United States Air Force and participate in a capstone event.

Way to go Thunderbirds!

At the Utah Military Academy, we strive to teach cadets how to process real world, big league decisions. Today, just a decision happened!

The other day, Cadet Enoch Horning received West Point Prep Appointment, which, done right, is simply an additional year at West Point. Today - the Naval Academy said the whole "prep" thing was a waste of a perfectly good year, and gave Cadet Horning a formal Appointment to Annapolis. Battling $500,000 scholarships.

What a conundrum!

Cadet Horning...the Army-Navy Football game has whole new meaning now. US Army Captain Josh Curtis is Okay if you go Navy, just so long as you sign an oath to NOT join the Marines. It would seem that Cadet Ross has that base covered via Annapolis, and we all need a Marine in the family, at least one. Thank you Cadet Ross.

So, Cadet Horning, what are you going to do?!

PS Maybe we run a Facebook 'call to action' poll to help Cadet Horning with this decision. After all, didn't Army win the last game? Captain Curtis, asking for a friend on this one.
